newsitem.title: CZECH REPUBLIC: Czech activists protest against altered soybeans.
newsitem.headline: Czech activists protest against altered soybeans.

text.p: Activists from the environmental group Greenpace on Tuesday staged a protest against the use of genetically-manipulated soybeans, blocking the entrance to the Czech headquarters of food maker Nestle SA.
Several protestors dressed up as laboratory rabbits formed a chain in front of the building.
Karel Jech of Greenpeace said the aim of the protest was to demand an assurance from firms like Nestle, Danone or Unilever, that they would not use manipulated commodities in the future.

"Soya beans growers in the U.S. are deciding now what kind of seeds to buy for the next year...We want the big companies to clearly say that they would not buy genetically altered beans," Jech told Reuters.

Nestle, the world's largest food company, has insisted that genetically modified soybeans are safe and of high quality and it intended to use them in its products despite protests from environmental activists. Its German arm, however, has agreed not to use the beans.
The Czech subsidiary of Nestle, Nestle Foods s.r.o., said in a statement that whether "in technology or materials, Nestle uses only those components which fulfil the highest international standards".
Greenpeace have been protesting against genetically altered foods, saying mutations might have yet unknown impacts on human health.
The U.S. firm Monsanto produces genetically-altered soybeans for sole use with a herbicide it has developed.
